comment.author: 54604085@N00
comment._content: A lot of great work here. I like this one because the funny element.

comment.author: 10213344@N07
comment._content: It looks like they are distributing some type of powder insectiside via the back of a wagon.  This shows how tough it was to do farming before John Deere came along. I live in the south and believe me there is no air or swimming pool nearby for them to dip in.

comment.author: 23259836@N08
comment._content: Not sure what is funny? This is probably rock phosphate which would change the ph of the soil.

comment.author: 80884048@N00
comment._content: These photos are incredibly beautiful and touching in a way. It's great to see actual documentation, moreover: in color, from this era. I laud this initiative.

comment.author: 54447542@N00
comment._content: I refer to color correcting the originals. They may be headed for trouble....once they go too far, it's too late.

comment.author: 82837610@N00
comment._content: They are spreading fertilizer or lime on the fields.

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content: Those are most definitely mules.  Note the one guy only drives, while the guy in back has to shovel the material into the hopper.  Must be the junior partner.

comment.author: 9984183@N04
comment._content:
Looks like the same team as in this photo 
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2178246883/in/set-72157603671370361/].

comment.author: 35339500@N00
comment._content: Heh heh, "junior partner."  There are no junior partners on farms.  You just do the work.  After an hour or so they probably switched places unless those mules would only obey the man driving.
